title-group.article-title: Investigating LGBTQ affirmative attitudes and needs for better practice among Hungarian healthcare professionals

article-meta.issue-title: Abstracts of the 32nd European Congress of Psychiatry

sec.title: Abstract
sec.p: Introduction: LGBTQ (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer) people often do not seek health care and do not identify as LGBTQ people because of fear of judgment, stereotyping, and discrimination by health professionals. All of this is a particularly worrying phenomenon, because various mental difficulties, risky behaviors, and certain types of somatic and psychosomatic diseases may appear in a higher proportion among them.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: Attitudes related to LGBTQ people were examined in several areas in Hungary. Most of our data comes from psychologists, however, a comprehensive examination of health professionals’ attitudes towards LGBTQ people has not yet been carried out.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: In a cross-sectional online survey, we ask healthcare professionals (medical doctors, nurses, other graduate healthcare professionals and medical university students) to fill out our questionnaire. The participants complete the Modern Homonegativity Scale and the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Clinical Skills Development Scale.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We assume that the majority of Hungarian healthcare professionals have a neutral or positive attitude towards LGBTQ people, but they struggle with a significant lack of affirmative skills. We will present our results in detail in the presentation of the symposium.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: There is an urgent need to provide the appropriate affirmative knowledge material to Hungarian healthcare workers.
